title.value: Stratifying the autistic phenotype using electrophysiological indices of social perception
title.justification: The title clearly indicates the focus of the study on using electrophysiological indices to stratify the autistic phenotype.
title.quote: Stratifying the autistic phenotype using electrophysiological indices of social perception

extractions.description: The paper evaluates the use of early-stage face processing speed, specifically N170 latency, as a clinical stratification factor for autism spectrum disorder (ASD). It investigates the correlation between N170 latency and socialization outcomes, brain responses via fMRI, and polygenic scores to improve strategies for personalized therapies for ASD.

type.justification: The study involves experiments and data analysis, including measuring N170 latency in individuals with ASD and comparing it to controls using empirical methods like EEG and fMRI.
type.quote: We sought to validate neural responses to faces as a potential stratification factor in ASD by measuring neural (electroencephalography) responses to faces (critical in social interaction) in N = 436 children and adults with and without ASD.

name.justification: The research focuses on electrophysiological indices, such as N170, in relation to social perception and autism, indicating a focus on both neuroscience and autism research.
name.quote: The N170 is a face-sensitive event-related potential of negative polarity peaking around 170 ms after stimulus onset over occipito-temporal electrodes.

name.justification: The study utilizes electrophysiological methods like EEG and neuroimaging techniques such as fMRI.
name.quote: Here, we focus on the N170 neural response to faces as a candidate stratification factor for social functioning in ASD.

name.justification: The research evaluates polygenic scores in relation to ASD, indicating a genetic epidemiology approach.
name.quote: N170 latency was associated with responses to faces in the fusiform gyrus, measured with functional magnetic resonance imaging, and polygenic scores for ASD.

name.justification: The study analyzes data from the Longitudinal European Autism Project, which contributes to its methodology and findings.
name.quote: We examined whether the N170 could be used for stratification according to social functioning in a large heterogeneous population of 436 individuals with ASD and controls tested in a multisite European longitudinal study [the Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP)].
